issueDTO.title: Introduce a meta scan function for inspecting table column size
issueDTO.description:
<!-- (At least include the following, feel free to add if you have more content) -->

## Feature request

StarRocks support several functions to inspect the metadata of segment files:
```sql
select count(id) from t1 [_META_];
select min(id) from t1 [_META_];
select max(id) from t1 [_META_];
select flat_json_meta(payload) from t1 [_META_];
```

Essentially it generates a `META_SCAN` operator to scan the metadata of underlying segment files, then aggregate the result with `count/min/max` functions.

We can leverage this mechanism to inspect the column size of a table, for example:

```sql
select column_size(id) from t1 [_META_];
```

There are several types of column sizes:  
- **Uncompressed Size**: Stored in the `ColumnMetaPB` located in the segment footer.  
- **Compressed Size**: Represents the on-disk size. While it is not explicitly stored in the footer, it can be estimated by analyzing the number of pages via the `OrdinalIndex` and calculating the average page size.  

It might be worthwhile to include a few functions for inspecting a column's metadata.

Further more, we can also consider add these column stats into the optimizer statistics system, stored in the `_statistics_.column_statistics` table.

repository.description: The world's fastest open query engine for sub-second analytics both on and off the data lakehouse. With the flexibility to support nearly any scenario, StarRocks provides best-in-class performance for multi-dimensional analytics, real-time analytics, and ad-hoc queries. A Linux Foundation project.
repository.name: starrocks

summary.main: Introduce a meta scan function for inspecting table column size, expanding on existing metadata inspection functions to include column size information, and considering integration with the optimizer statistics system.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the meta scan function to accurately inspect the column size of a table, considering both uncompressed and compressed sizes, and to be compatible with existing metadata inspection functions.
summary.attemptedFixes: The fix involves introducing a meta scan function for inspecting table column size, specifically for handling uncompressed and compressed sizes, and potentially integrating the column stats into the optimizer statistics system.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is considered a feature request and a good first issue, making it suitable for a contributor to tackle.

issueDTO.title: Add example for using `EsploraClient` with timeout configuration
issueDTO.description:
## Feature Request

An example showing how to configure and use `EsploraClient` with custom timeout settings would be helpful for developers using BDK with unreliable or slow network connections.

### Why?

Currently, the documentation does not illustrate how to:
- Set custom request timeouts when using `EsploraClient`
- Handle timeout-related errors gracefully

### Whatâ€™s Expected?

Please add a simple example (in the `examples/` directory) demonstrating:
- Instantiating `EsploraClient` with a custom `ureq::Agent`
- Setting timeout durations (connect/read/write)
- Making a sample call (e.g., `get_height` or `get_tx`) with the client

### Example Reference

The relevant code might look like:

```rust
let agent = ureq::AgentBuilder::new()
    .timeout_connect(Duration::from_secs(10))
    .timeout_read(Duration::from_secs(30))
    .timeout_write(Duration::from_secs(30))
    .build();

let esplora_client = EsploraClient::from_agent("https://blockstream.info/api", agent);

repository.description: A modern, lightweight, descriptor-based wallet library written in Rust!
repository.name: bdk_wallet

summary.main: The issue is that the documentation does not provide an example or illustration on how to set custom request timeouts when using EsploraClient, leading to difficulties for developers when using BDK with unreliable or slow network connections.
summary.validationOrRequirement: According to the documentation, it's expected that developers using BDK with unreliable or slow network connections should be able to set custom request timeouts when using EsploraClient and handle timeout-related errors gracefully.
summary.attemptedFixes: The addition of an example showing how to configure and use EsploraClient with custom timeout settings should be implemented. This would involve adding a Rust code example in the 'examples/' directory demonstrating the instantiation of EsploraClient with a custom ureq::Agent, setting timeout durations, making a sample call, and handling timeout-related errors gracefully.
summary.otherNotes: The issue 'Add example for using EsploraClient with timeout configuration' is currently labeled as 'documentation' and 'good first issue', indicating it's a suitable task for a contributor to tackle.

issueDTO.title: Support optional object type attributes in Nomad HCL variables
issueDTO.description:
### Proposal

Support `optional(...)` in object type attributes, similar to the [equivalent feature from Terraform](https://developer.hashicorp.com/terraform/language/expressions/type-constraints#optional-object-type-attributes)

### Use-cases

Variables that use complex types (e.g. `list(object({ ... }))`, where some fields are optional, currently have to be specified in full, or have to be defined as maps where the burden of type validation falls on the template author.

### Attempted Solutions

* Using a `type = map(string)` and checking each field for existence/type-correctness
* Using a `type = string`, setting the value to some structured data format, like JSON or YAML, which is then `(yaml|json)decode`d and its contents' fields checked for existence/type-correctness
comments: Hi @atavakoliyext and thanks for raising this issue. I think supporting the `type` definition within job specification variables in a similar manner to Terraform makes sense. I'll move this onto our roadmapping list.
Great to hear, thank you! I look forward to seeing where it lands on your roadmap 🙂
This seems like a good improvement, always thought this was actually supported. @jrasell I would love to take a crack at it.

I have been digging a bit. Seems like using `typeexpr.TypeConstraintWithDefaults` instead of `typeexpr.Type` https://github.com/hashicorp/nomad/blob/493e7b2faadc56cbd2057b84d0576ca74c4832aa/jobspec2/types.variables.go#L291-L298 from the `github.com/hashicorp/hcl/v2/ext/typeexpr` lib in  should add the optional (with default value support) for the variables.
Checking further to see if this has any unintended downstream effect.

repository.description: Nomad is an easy-to-use, flexible, and performant workload orchestrator that can deploy a mix of microservice, batch, containerized, and non-containerized applications. Nomad is easy to operate and scale and has native Consul and Vault integrations.
repository.name: nomad

summary.main: The issue proposes supporting `optional(...)` in object type attributes in Nomad HCL variables, specifically for variables that use complex types, such as lists of objects with optional fields, to simplify type definition and validation.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is to support optional object type attributes in Nomad HCL variables, similar to the feature in Terraform, allowing for more flexibility in defining complex types and reducing the need for explicit type validation in templates.
summary.attemptedFixes: One possible solution suggested is using `typeexpr.TypeConstraintWithDefaults` instead of `typeexpr.Type` from the `github.com/hashicorp/hcl/v2/ext/typeexpr` lib, specifically line 291-298 in the `jobspec2/types.variables.go` file, to add optional attribute with default value support for variables.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is currently labeled as 'enhancement', 'good first issue', and has been accepted for implementation. The discussion has provided a proposal, use-cases, and attempted solutions, with one commenter beginning to investigate the solution.

issueDTO.description:
## Guideline

## What should I do if I have a problem
1. Try to google it before asking. Googling is taking major part of dev work 
2. If you couldn't find answer your question with Google, text your question to [dev](https://t.me/spotnet_dev/4) group with your question.

   ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cb26457a-78c3-4f47-bdc6-876f4b917848)

It will be calculated by summing the token amounts across all `user_pools` and multiplying them by their current prices, as defined in [this issue](https://github.com/djeck1432/spotnet/issues/909).

issueDTO.title: Fork, Commit, Merge - Medium Issue 2 (React.js)
issueDTO.description:
# Fork, Commit, Merge - Medium Issue 2 (React.js)

## Create a Traffic Light Component
*Note: You don't have ask permission to start solving the issue or get assigned, since these issues are supposed to be always open for new contributors. The actions-user bot will reset the file back to previous state for the next contributor after your commit is merged. So you can just simply start working with the issue right away!*

### How to get started:

Start by navigating inside of the directory used in this project with the command:
```bash
cd tasks/react/medium/traffic-light
```

Then run `npm i` to install Vite, React and all the necessary dependencies for the project.

After installing the dependencies you can open the `src` directory and the `TrafficLight.tsx` file, and start implementing your solution!

![react-medium](https://github.com/fork-commit-merge/fork-commit-merge/assets/82566656/e154750d-41fd-4db4-bcc6-9dd52c7e55d6)

### Description:

Create a React component using TypeScript that simulates a traffic light. The component should display three lights (red, yellow, and green) and switch between them automatically in the order of a typical traffic light sequence.

### Requirements:

-   Implement a `TrafficLight` component in `src/TrafficLight.tsx`.
-   Use TypeScript for type safety.
-   The component should render three circles, colored red, yellow, and green.
-   The traffic light should start with the red light.
-   After a few seconds, it should change to green, then yellow, and then back to red in a continuous loop.
-   Only one light should be "active" (brighter) at a time.

There are some CSS classes already added for you in the `src/App.css` file, which you can use if you like, or write your own custom CSS.
There is for example a helper pseudo-class selector for every light that is not active, which will set the light color to gray if the light does not have the `active` class:

![react-medium-css](https://github.com/fork-commit-merge/fork-commit-merge/assets/82566656/052aaf61-e4d9-40b9-8876-bf96aa2ada9c)

### Example:

The traffic light should cycle as follows:

-   Red (active) for 4 seconds.
-   Green (active) for 3 seconds.
-   Yellow (active) for 1 second.
-   Repeat the cycle.

## How to run:
After you are done with the card, make sure you are in the `tasks/react/medium/traffic-light` in your terminal and run `npm run dev` to start the Vite server. Then, open "http://localhost:5173/" in your browser to check how the app looks.

If it looks to be working fine, you are ready to make a pull request!

---

To work with this issue, you need to have npm and NodeJS installed to your local machine.
Check out [README.md](https://github.com/nikohoffren/fork-commit-merge/blob/main/README.md) for more instructions of installing npm and NodeJS as well as how to make a pull request.

---

## Why use Vite?

This React project uses Vite for near-instant server start-ups and incredibly fast hot module replacements, providing a smooth and efficient development experience.
Also Vite requires minimal setup, allowing us to focus on writing React code without getting bogged down in complex configurations.
If you want to learn more about Vite, check out the documentation:
[Vite Official Documentation](https://vitejs.dev/)

---

Feel free to ask any questions here if you have some problems!

#### Also, kindly give this project a star to enhance its visibility for new developers!

issueDTO.title: Optimise performance of var-args functions by adding loop-unrolled variants
issueDTO.description:
### Is your feature request related to a problem?

There are a variety of `MultiArgFunction` functions, with variable argument lists. Often, these lists will be short (<5 arguments), but there is no guarantee that the JVM will unroll their loops automatically.

Functions that perform relatively simple operations may benefit from manually unrolled variants that skip loop and conditional checks, and instead have a straight bytecode path for the calculations.



### Describe the solution you'd like.

Review var-args functions, particularly those with numeric arguments and basic calculations. If they are a candidate for loop unrolling, implement and benchmark to prove it is faster.

Examples of var-args functions:

- greatest/least
- IN
- CASE
- coalesce
- ~l2price~
- concat

### Describe alternatives you've considered.

_No response_

### Full Name:

Nick Woolmer

### Affiliation:

QuestDB

### Additional context

_No response_

For sure, go for it. `l2price` already has unrolled variants, so you can use that as a reference of what can be achieved for the other functions.

issueDTO.title: Create CONTRIBUTORS.md to acknowledge all project contributors
issueDTO.description:
## Description
We need to create a CONTRIBUTORS.md file to properly acknowledge and give credit to all the people who have contributed to the ruv-FANN project.

## Motivation
- Recognize the valuable contributions from the community
- Provide transparency about who has helped build this project
- Encourage future contributions by showing appreciation

## Implementation Plan
1. **Gather Contributors**
   - Review all GitHub issues and pull requests
   - Start with @ruvnet as the project creator
   - Include all contributors who have:
     - Submitted merged PRs
     - Reported issues that led to improvements
     - Provided valuable feedback or ideas
     - Contributed to documentation

2. **CONTRIBUTORS.md Format**
   ```markdown
   # Contributors

   Thank you to all the contributors who have helped make ruv-FANN better!

   ## Project Creator
   - **[ruvnet](https://github.com/ruvnet)** - Project creator and maintainer

   ## Code Contributors
   - [Contributor Name](https://github.com/username) - Brief description of contributions

   ## Issue Contributors
   - [Contributor Name](https://github.com/username) - Reported issues #X, #Y

   ## Documentation Contributors
   - [Contributor Name](https://github.com/username) - Improved documentation
   ```

3. **Process for Future Contributors**
   - Update CONTRIBUTORS.md when merging significant PRs
   - Include a note in PR template about contributor recognition
   - Consider automating with GitHub Actions in the future

## Tasks
- [ ] Create initial CONTRIBUTORS.md file
- [ ] Review all issues and PRs to identify contributors
- [ ] Add contributors with appropriate categories
- [ ] Submit PR with the new file
- [ ] Update contributing guidelines to mention contributor recognition

cc @ruvnet - This issue tracks the creation of a contributors file to acknowledge everyone who has helped with the project.

issueDTO.title: Config flashes before "Loading" screen on subdomains
issueDTO.description:
When opening page on a subdomain for the first time, config flashes at the bottom of the page:

> [screen-recorder-fri-dec-13-2024-17-29-57.webm](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/899f9c22-5489-4ba6-ae0a-0687f7d89c9a)


This likely occurs when default index.html loads in iframe to read config. 
We should hide entire DOM if URL is landing page (no path, no subdomain).
comments: Can you assign me this issue, I would love to resolve this.
@Winter-Soren please feel free to work on this and open a PR :)

This seems to be happening again on inbrowser.link and .dev.

Let's take an opportunity to  improve the UI.

Good idea from @autonome:

> would be super cool if that interstitial had all website ui removed, just be a loading animation in the middle, with a very short msg communicating the value of the wait

related ideas:
- reuse fullscreen animation from the header of  [helia.io](https://helia.io/)?  
- reuse heartbeat css from ipfs-companion?
- have text that says "initializing Service Worker... TIP: visit `inbrowser.link` to adjust settings" ?

@lidel We *have* to show the iframe or it wont load config from global domain. do we still want that functionality?

config iframe started showing again in https://github.com/ipfs/service-worker-gateway/pull/677

One thing we can do with config loading from root that I forgot about until just now was the get config JSON call to the SW.. instead of loading the UI (dealing with defaults, async loading issues, and UI delays, etc.) the iframe config should simply query the SW-config `await fetch('?ipfs-sw-config-get=true')` and post that to the subdomain page (the parent of the iframe)..

Can we return an HTML page that simply handles "postMessage" directly from the service worker...? e.g.

```
<iframe src=`${parentDomain}?ipfs-sw-config-get-for-subdomain=true` />
```

> We have to show the iframe or it wont load config from global domain

This seems to fail sporadically. For example, when loading `/ipns/vitalik.eth` (I made sure the origin's local data was cleared before), it seems like there's a race condition and it doesn't have enough time for the config to load from the main origin (see the `enableRecursiveGateways` config).

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/20d20eae-92ca-450f-af7e-746340d10b63)

> the iframe config should simply query the SW-config await fetch('?ipfs-sw-config-get=true') and post that to the subdomain page (the parent of the iframe)

This sounds like a good idea both from a UX perspective as it would reduce the rendering overhead incurred by loading the config UI. 

However, if we cannot get config to reliably load from the root domain (`inbrowser.link`), I think global config is more misleading than helpful.

This probably needs to be revisited after #757 is addressed.

Have static HTML+CSS that by default shows loading screen, so if it flashes during those redirects, then it is a meaningful loading message, and not a janky UI flash.

Anecdotally, https://bafkreibm6jg3ux5qumhcn2b3flc3tyu6dmlb4xa7u5bf44yegnrjhc4yeq.ipfs.inbrowser.link/  on cold load requires fetching 2.4MiB and takes 2.86 seconds on my 500Mbit fiber and ~12s on 3G

this should be fixed with the latest deployment of v1.13.4 to inbrowser.dev: https://github.com/ipfs/service-worker-gateway/actions/runs/15902783209

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e916380a-d90e-4940-b436-008ab3fe1d35

Nice, way better experience than seeing a full-frame of content!

Is there a way to remove the first icon flash?

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/067182d0-3f16-4984-a08f-d2a8e8d916a5)

@autonome it's currently hardcoded in the HTML, so it shows 3 times currently with v1.13.4: 
1. on first hit to subdomain (html,css,js downloaded, browser renders content, runs js, redirects to root)
2. on hit to root domain (same scenario as above, except you may have css/html/js cached in your browser, and redirects to subdomain with config values)
3. on final landing on subdomain, assets are cached, and the content of the page is displayed while SW is registered, and `window.location.replace` is called that is intercepted by the SW

So I am thinking I can delay showing the loading icon entirely until that last item above.

Happy to go with what users are thinking will work best.. or any clever solutions to render something more pleasing to the eye. I'll be trying to get some live feedback from @2color and @lidel on this sometime this week too.

> [@autonome](https://github.com/autonome) it's currently hardcoded in the HTML, so it shows 3 times currently with v1.13.4:
> 
> So I am thinking I can delay showing the loading icon entirely until that last item above.

+1

doing any work before the first redirect in the worst case scenario (nothing cached) guarantees a worse visual experience, since another redirect (visual flash) is guaranteed.

pushing all work to after 2nd redirect _might_ be better, but would need some testing to understand whether it could cause too long of a delay with no visual indicator at all.

>  redirects to subdomain with config values

(sorry i'm out of the loop on this work, feel free to link me to something to rtfm)

what are these values and why can't they shipped out to the client w/o the double redirect?

> > redirects to subdomain with config values > > (sorry i'm out of the loop on this work, feel free to link me to something to rtfm) > > what are these values and why can't they shipped out to the client w/o the double redirect? The config values determine some of the parameters for Verified Fetch and how retrieval works: We currently redirect so that users can change the configuration for subdomain origins, e.g. `cid.ipfs.inbrowser.link`. The reason we do this is because it's not clear from a UX perspective how to best allow users to change configuration for subdomains without modifying the verified response. The "insider way to do this is to append `/#/ipfs-sw-config` to the subdomain URI which will load the config page. @SgtPooki and I discussed some ideas on how to solve this: - Add a query parameter to disable the config redirect - Removing the config redirect by default (also a minor perf win) - Using the IPFS Companion extension to detect the SW and either allowing config from there or a button linking you to the config hash fragment

for now I think the config redirect is a pretty good improvement while not adding much latency. It is also extremely useful for testing, tbh, but also some potential future privacy/security concerns. We can disable or adjust easily in the future once we get the config in companion or get more feedback that folks really don't care about the shared config at all.

issueDTO.title: Support parsing MySQL stored procedure syntax - part 0
issueDTO.description:
# Background
Hi community,

ShardingSphere's parser engine enables users to parse SQL into AST (Abstract Syntax Tree) and convert it into SQLStatement objects. 
This issue focuses on enhancing MySQL stored procedure parsing capabilities to support complex database programming logic.

More details:
https://shardingsphere.apache.org/document/current/en/reference/sharding/parse/

# Issue Background Explanation

These SQL statements are from the official MySQL test set. 
You can find the corresponding stored procedure SQL statements in the following website: https://github.com/mysql/mysql-server/tree/8.0/mysql-test/t 
These SQL cases are then passed to ShardingSphere's parsing engine for analysis. 
For SQL cases that fail to be parsed successfully, every 3 to 5 SQL cases are grouped together as an issue.
1. It cannot be guaranteed that all SQL cases are correct. Please follow the following process to handle this pull request (PR).
2. Some SQL cases may have already been fixed in other PRs. For cases that can already be executed successfully, simply leave a comment to ignore them.
3. If a SQL case can be executed successfully without any code changes, there is no need to add a corresponding test assert file.

# Task
This issue requires adding support for the following MySQL stored procedure syntax:
```sql
-- The original file and line number of the sql: analyze:85 
CREATE PROCEDURE p() ANALYZE TABLE v UPDATE HISTOGRAM ON w
```

```sql
-- The original file and line number of the sql: change_user_deadlock:35 
END |
CREATE PROCEDURE p_processlist()
BEGIN
DECLARE x INT DEFAULT 3000
```

```sql
-- The original file and line number of the sql: change_user_deadlock:26 
CREATE PROCEDURE p_flush_status()
BEGIN
DECLARE x INT DEFAULT 3000
```

```sql
-- The original file and line number of the sql: clear_diag_area:254 
CREATE PROCEDURE p7_show_warnings ()
BEGIN
SHOW VARIABLES LIKE 'foo';
SHOW WARNINGS;
SELECT "(SHOW WARNINGS does not have to come last)";
END
```

```sql
-- The original file and line number of the sql: clear_diag_area:263 
CREATE PROCEDURE p8b_show_warnings ()
BEGIN
SHOW WARNINGS;
END
```


# Overall Procedure
If you intend to participate in fixing this issue, please feel free to leave a comment below the issue. Community members will assign the issue accordingly.
For example, you can leave a comment like this: "Hi, please assign this issue to me. Thank you!"

Once you have claimed the issue, please review the syntax of the SQL on the official website of the corresponding database. 
Execute the SQL on the respective database to ensure the correctness of the SQL syntax.

You can check the corresponding source of each SQL case on the official database website.
Next, execute the problematic SQL cases mentioned above in the database (you can quickly start the corresponding database using the Docker image for that database, and then connect to it using a client you are  familiar with), to ensure that the SQL syntax itself is correct.


Once you have confirmed the correctness of the SQL syntax, you can validate and fix the grammar parsing issue in ShardingSphere.
>If you are using IntelliJ IDEA, you will need to install the ANTLR plugin before proceeding.
If it is an ANTLR parsing error message, try to repair the `.g4` file by comparing it with the official database syntax until the SQL can be correctly parsed by ANTLR.
When there is no error message in the ANTLR Preview window, it means that ANTLR can correctly parse the SQL.


After ANTLR parses SQL into an abstract syntax tree, ShardingSphere will access the abstract syntax tree through Visitor and extract the required information.
If you need to extract Segments, you need to first execute:
```shell
mvn -T 2C clean install -DskipTests
```
Under the shardingsphere-parser module to compile the entire parser module.
Then rewrite the corresponding visit method in SQLStatementVisitorr as needed to extract the corresponding Segment.


After the above SQL parsing problem is repaired, the corresponding Test needs to be added.
The steps are as follows:
1. Add the corresponding `sql-case` in the `sql/supported` directory.
2. Add case assertions in the case directory of the `shardingsphere-test-it-parser` module.
3. Run `org.apache.shardingsphere.test.it.sql.parser.internal.InternalSQLParserIT`
After SQL Parser IT runs successfully, you can submit a PR.


1. Master JAVA language
2. Have a basic understanding of Antlr g4 file
3. Be familiar with MySQL SQLs

issueDTO.title: Fork, Commit, Merge - Easy Issue (Solid.js)
issueDTO.description:
# Fork, Commit, Merge - Easy Issue (Solid.js)

## Implement a Simple Counter in Solid.js

In this task, you will implement a simple counter using the Solid.js framework. This will help you learn the basics of reading and updating signals in Solid.js.

---
***Note: You don't have ask permission to start solving the issue or get assigned, since these issues are supposed to be always open for new contributors. The actions-user bot will reset the file back to previous state for the next contributor after your commit is merged. So you can just simply start working with the issue right away!***

Issue created by ***![zshaian](https://github.com/zshaian)***.

## Getting Started

You can start by navigating to the folder `./task/solid/easy`

Once you are on that folder you can then install the packages that you are going to need to run Solid.js framework, you can do so by running `npm i`

After installing the dependencies you can open the src directory and App.jsx file, and start implementing your solution!

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/682663cd-4af6-4c69-b3f7-4e8e41bfb798)

**All the CSS classes needed in this project has already been done for you in index.css and app.module.css.**

## Requiremets:

- Implement the counter state with the name of "count" and a setter named "setCount"
- Display the current count
- Increment or Decrement the count state using the "setCount"

If you can display the current count and increment or decrement it based on the buttons, you are ready to make a pull request.

---
To work with this issue, you need to have npm and NodeJS installed to your local machine.
Check out [README.md](https://github.com/fork-commit-merge/fork-commit-merge/blob/main/README.md) for more instructions of installing npm and NodeJS as well as how to make a pull request.

Feel free to ask any questions here if you have some problems!

**Also, kindly give this project a star to enhance its visibility for new developers!**

summary.main: The `onCreateUser` method in Meteor is currently documented incorrectly in regards to the temporary user `_Id`. The issue arises because the `insertUserDoc` function generates a new `_id` after the hook and overwrites the original value. This causes orphaned documents to be created when seeding sibling collections with the provisional `_id` value.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the documentation to accurately reflect the behavior of `onCreateUser` and the provisional nature of the `_id` value. The `_id` value should not be used for seeding sibling collections.
summary.attemptedFixes: The fix can be implemented by updating the documentation to clarify that the `_id` received in `Accounts.onCreateUser` is provisional and will be replaced unless the hook sets its own `_id`. Optional enhancement could be made to keep the set value instead of overwriting it.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is labeled as 'Project:Docs', 'missing-docs', 'Type:Bug', and 'good first issue' indicating that it's a significant issue suitable for a contributor to tackle. A pull request should be submitted targeting the main branch with clear documentation on the `_id` in `onCreateUser` stating that it's a provisional value and will be replaced unless the hook sets its own `_id`.

issueDTO.description:
When we first developed a demo app for speech to text, `react-native-audio-api` didn't provide any features to gather mic input, but it does now.  The scope of this task is to change usages of `react-native-live-audio-stream` to `react-native-audio-api` from the following sources: 
https://docs.swmansion.com/react-native-executorch/docs/natural-language-processing/useSpeechToText#live-data-microphone-transcription
https://github.com/software-mansion/react-native-executorch/blob/9082057240c92e1e0d602b52b0ab572e7320f55f/apps/speech-to-text/screens/SpeechToTextScreen.tsx#L11
comments:

issueDTO.title: Option to "Add this element to collection elements" in "Open webpage in new tab" action
issueDTO.description: We need that a cell that open a website is added to collection elements. We think that the best is to add an option similar to Navigate to other grid action.
comments: should be solved in a generic way, see #514

So, we understand that it's not possible to collect the cell to the current sentence, isn't it? As yo comment on #504 "action like navigation or an external action like HTTP shouldn't be collected to the current sentence" and we don't say an option to force to add it to collect element. So, we understand is not possible.

Currently elements with some kinds of actions like HTTP or navigation to other grid etc. are not collected to collection element. For action `navigate to other grid` we have the option to override this behaviour (`add to collect element despite navigation`). I think this option should be available for all kinds of actions which prevent adding to collect element by default. The generic option should be named something like `force to add element to collect element` and maybe it should be in general -> advanced instead of at configuring the action?!

We already have this global setting:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/39f1ea33-7a48-4226-b726-054e827b1fd4)

So maybe this should be a dropdown with values: `automatic` (default), `don't add to collect element` and `add to collect element`

> Currently elements with some kinds of actions like HTTP or navigation to other grid etc. are not collected to collection element. For action `navigate to other grid` we have the option to override this behaviour (`add to collect element despite navigation`). I think this option should be available for all kinds of actions which prevent adding to collect element by default. The generic option should be named something like `force to add element to collect element` and maybe it should be in general -> advanced instead of at configuring the action?!

ok, understand. 

> So maybe this should be a dropdown with values: `automatic` (default), `don't add to collect element` and `add to collect element`

Yes, we think that it would be the best solution. 

Thanks

issueDTO.title: Fork, Commit, Merge - Medium Issue (Python)
issueDTO.description:
# Fork, Commit, Merge - Medium Issue (Python)

## Implement Bubble Sort Algorithm in Python
*Note: You don't have ask permission to start solving the issue or get assigned, since these issues are supposed to be always open for new contributors. The actions-user bot will reset the file back to previous state for the next contributor after your commit is merged. So you can just simply start working with the issue right away!*

## How to get started

Start by opening the `tasks/python/medium` directory from the root of the project. 
Then open `bubble_sort.py` file and start working on your solution!

![python-medium](https://github.com/nikohoffren/fork-commit-merge/assets/82566656/b32978ed-2a26-48d8-9bd4-322cf1916586)

## Description

The goal of this issue is to implement the bubble sort algorithm in Python. The function should be able to sort an array of integers in ascending order. You should create a function called `bubble_sort` to accomplish this.
*Note: Do not use the `sort` function or any similar methods to solve this task.*

## How to run

Make sure you are in the right directory:

```bash
cd tasks/python/medium
```

Execute the following command to run your Python script:

```bash
python bubble_sort.py
```

## Expected output

```bash
Original array: [64, 25, 12, 22, 11]
Sorted array: [11, 12, 22, 25, 64]
```

If the output looks correct, you are ready to make a pull request!

---

To work with this issue, you need to have Python installed to your local machine.
Check out [README.md](https://github.com/nikohoffren/fork-commit-merge/blob/main/README.md) for more instructions of installing Python and how to make a pull request.

Feel free to ask any questions here if you have some problems!

#### Also, kindly give this project a star to enhance its visibility for new developers!

issueDTO.title: Type Scheme Ordering causes ast_transform_test to fail
issueDTO.description:
In some rare cases, the variable order for multiple variable in a type scheme is transformed differently.

```erlang
1) ast_transform_test:-all_file_test_/0-fun-0-/0: test_files/ast_transform/funspec.erl                  
     Failure/Error: ?assert(false)                                                                        
       expected: true                                                                                     
            got: false                                                                                    
     %% lists.erl:2641:in `lists:foreach_1/2`                                                             
     Output: Test in test_files/ast_transform/funspec.erl:0 failed: AST does not have the right form after
 transformation. Diff (--- expected, +++ given):                                                          
--- ./terms_1_123-1329437-29778DD.erl   2025-07-02 13:49:48.691268532 +0200                               
+++ ./terms_2_163-1329437-22EBB1F.erl   2025-07-02 13:49:48.691268532 +0200                               
@@ -1,7 +1,7 @@                                                                                           
 [{attribute,{loc,[],0,0},module,funcall},                                                                
  {attribute,{loc,[],0,0},                                                                                
             spec,foo,1,                                                                                  
-            {ty_scheme,[{'Y',{predef_alias,number}},{'_X',{predef,atom}}],                               
+            {ty_scheme,[{'_X',{predef,atom}},{'Y',{predef_alias,number}}],                               
                        {intersection,[{fun_full,[{tuple,[{var,'_X'},{predef,integer}]}],{var,'_X'}},{fun_
full,[{tuple,[{var,'_X'},{list,{var,'Y'}}]}],{var,'Y'}}]}},                                               
             without_mod},                                                                                
  {function,{loc,[],0,0},foo,1,[{fun_clause,{loc,[],0,0},[{wildcard,{loc,[],0,0}}],[],[{atom,{loc,[],0,0},
ok}]}]}]                                                                                                  
\ No newline at end of file                                                                               
                                                                                                          
     Output: Test in test_files/ast_transform/funspec.erl:0 failed: AST does not have the right form after
 transformation. Diff (--- expected, +++ given):                                                          
--- ./terms_1_123-1329437-29778DD.erl   2025-07-02 13:49:48.691268532 +0200
+++ ./terms_2_163-1329437-22EBB1F.erl   2025-07-02 13:49:48.691268532 +0200
@@ -1,7 +1,7 @@
 [{attribute,{loc,[],0,0},module,funcall},
  {attribute,{loc,[],0,0}, 
             spec,foo,1,
-            {ty_scheme,[{'Y',{predef_alias,number}},{'_X',{predef,atom}}],
+            {ty_scheme,[{'_X',{predef,atom}},{'Y',{predef_alias,number}}],
                        {intersection,[{fun_full,[{tuple,[{var,'_X'},{predef,integer}]}],{var,'_X'}},{fun_
full,[{tuple,[{var,'_X'},{list,{var,'Y'}}]}],{var,'Y'}}]}},
             without_mod}, 
  {function,{loc,[],0,0},foo,1,[{fun_clause,{loc,[],0,0},[{wildcard,{loc,[],0,0}}],[],[{atom,{loc,[],0,0},
ok}]}]}]
```

This is the module to be transformed:

```erlang
-module(funspec).
-spec foo({_X, integer()}) -> _X when _X :: atom()
         ; ({_X, [Y]}) -> Y when Y :: number().
foo(_) -> ok.
```

The test failure is caused by the non-deterministic order of type variables in the generated `ty_scheme` attribute during AST transformation.
* The test expects type variables in the order: [{'Y', ...}, {'_X', ...}]
* The actual transformation produces: [{'_X', ...}, {'Y', ...}]

Check where (or if) the variable order for Erlang is defined and if we are transforming it correctly. If it is undefined, maybe it is better to sort them to not get non-deterministic behavior.

repository.description: Static typechecker for Erlang
repository.name: etylizer

summary.main: The type scheme ordering causes the ast_transform_test to fail, resulting in unexpected output that does not match the expected behavior; this issue needs to be addressed to ensure the correct transformation and proper output.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for type variables to be consistently ordered in every instance of the generated ty_scheme attribute, specific to Erlang's syntax and type definition rules; the issue needs to be resolved to avoid non-deterministic behavior in the typechecker.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue may be resolved by investigating and clarifying the variable order for Erlang type schemes during AST transformation, possibly by introducing sorting to ensure consistent order. If not defined, a non-deterministic order could be the cause of the issue.

issueDTO.title: bug:  `kflex` fails when `kflex-initial-ctx-name` is invalid
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the bug

`kflex create cp1` fails when the kubeconfig contains a  `kflex-initial-ctx-name` pointing to an invalid contexts

```shell
kflex create cp1
âœ” Checking for saved initial context...
âœ” Switching to initial context...
Error getting client: error building kubeconfig: invalid configuration: [context was not found for specified context: kind-kubeflex, cluster has no server defined]
```

### Steps To Reproduce

1. kflex init -c
2. kind delete clusters --all
3. oc login ....
4. helm upgrade --install kubeflex-operator chart/ --namespace kubeflex-system --set isOpenShift=true

the `kubeconfig` still contains something like:

```yaml
preferences:
  extensions:
  - extension:
      data:
        kflex-initial-ctx-name: kind-kubeflex
      metadata:
        creationTimestamp: null
        name: kflex-config-extension-name
    name: kflex-config-extension-name
```

Then 

```shell
kflex create cp1
âœ” Checking for saved initial context...
âœ” Switching to initial context...
Error getting client: error building kubeconfig: invalid configuration: [context was not found for specified context: kind-kubeflex, cluster has no server defined]
```

### Expected Behavior

`kflex` should check on the validity of `kflex-initial-ctx-name` before using it.
If it is not valid, ignore it, assume that it was not enetered before

### Additional Context

_No response_
comments:
I find that with KubeFlex 0.6.3, if the extension stores the name of a context that exists but is not working, this is an unrecoverable state: no `kflex ctx` command will fix it. For example, I set the extension to say the hosting context is "kscore-stage" at a time when that context exists but is unusable. Then:

```console
mspreitz@mjs13 kubestellar % kubectl config use-context kind-kubeflex
Switched to context "kind-kubeflex".

mspreitz@mjs13 kubestellar % kflex ctx wds1
kubeconfig context wds1 not found (context wds1 not found), trying to load from server...
â— Switching to context wds1...Error getting kf client: error creating NewDiscoveryRESTMapper: Get "https://c115-e.us-south.containers.cloud.ibm.com:30486/api": dial tcp 50.22.129.34:30486: connect: connection refused

mspreitz@mjs13 kubestellar % kflex ctx
âœ” Checking for saved hosting cluster context...
âœ” Switching to hosting cluster context...

mspreitz@mjs13 kubestellar % kubectl config current-context
kscore-stage

mspreitz@mjs13 kubestellar % yq .preferences ${KUBECONFIG:-$HOME/.kube/config}
extensions:
  - extension:
      data:
        kflex-initial-ctx-name: kscore-stage
      metadata:
        creationTimestamp: null
        name: kflex-config-extension-name
    name: kflex-config-extension-name
```
Note also that https://docs.kubestellar.io/release-0.24.0/direct/get-started/ does not invoke `kflex init` or `kflex create`, it only has `kflex ctx` commands.

Hi @MikeSpreitzer ! I'm interested in working on this issue. Based on my understanding, the problem occurs when KubeFlex tries to use a stored context from the kubeconfig extensions that is either invalid or no longer exists.

I'm planning to implement a solution that would:
1. Validate the stored context before using it
2. Add proper fallback logic when an invalid context is detected
3. Provide clear user feedback about what's happening

Is this approach aligned with what you're looking for? Are there any additional considerations I should be aware of before I start working on a PR?

UPDATE:

Starting #386 - kubeflex changes its usage of kubeconfig extensions (see https://github.com/kubestellar/kubeflex/blob/main/docs/users.md#v090)

In kubeflex, extensions are easier to use thanks to our internal package https://github.com/kubestellar/kubeflex/tree/main/pkg/kubeconfig

As consequences, the key `kflex-initial-ctx-name` is outdated. Have a look to the new consts https://github.com/kubestellar/kubeflex/tree/main/pkg/kubeconfig/extensions.go 

CC: @francostellari @Rupam-It
@francostellari can i work on this

@blazethunderstorm go for it. 

However, be mindful of these changes specified on the following comment https://github.com/kubestellar/kubeflex/issues/202#issuecomment-2965651600
@rxinui alright would take care of that
@blazethunderstorm are you still working on this issue?
@Arpit529Srivastava yes would make its pr today only

issueDTO.title: How do I distinguish the role in Aurora-MySQL?
issueDTO.description:
I saw that the [code](https://github.com/qonto/prometheus-rds-exporter/blob/88950eb83a655301eb41ab39e186be94d415fed4/internal/app/rds/helper.go#L111 ) updates the role value to either primary or replica.
For engine: MySQL, this seems normal, but for engine: Aurora-MySQL, all instances are marked as primary (not reader or writer).
comments: Hey, this project was mainly built for RDS PostgreSQL and we don't guarantee Aurora support yet. Don't hesitate to contribute if you know what could help update the role value.

We are following interest for Aurora in #46. It's indeed de facto a bit confusing because Aurora instances are detected, but role is not accurate. The role values `primary/replica` for RDS and `writer/reader` for Aurora are also very different. Some users may have mix of RDS and Aurora clusters. Having same role names for RDS and Aurora will simplify dashboards and alerts, but are inaccurate regarding AWS terms. @ZacharyZhuoOpenNet in term of experience, are you expecting to have same role names for Aurora and RDS? @ZacharyZhuoOpenNet Please upvote on #46 as we may have an update on Aurora support this year

Hello,
I'm starting the development to add proper support of Aurora, I'll share my pull request in https://github.com/qonto/prometheus-rds-exporter/issues/46

issueDTO.title: 'no_proxy' env var not evaluated
issueDTO.description:
### Steps To Reproduce

1.Set `http_proxy`, `https_proxy` and `no_proxy` env vars (including the bitwarden server in `no_proxy`).
2. Execute a Bitwarden CLI command (example: 'bw list items')

### Expected Result

The Bitwarden CLI should respect the `no_proxy` variable and don't use the proxy.

### Actual Result

The Bitwarden CLI will try to send a post request to the Bitwarden server using the proxy.

### Screenshots or Videos

_No response_

### Additional Context

This behavior was observed on Linux. I can't state if the behavior on other OSes is comparable.

### Operating System

Linux

### Operating System Version

Ubuntu 24.04.2 LTS

### Shell

Bash

### Build Version

2025.1.3

### Issue Tracking Info

- [x] I understand that work is tracked outside of Github. A PR will be linked to this issue should one be opened to address it, but Bitwarden doesn't use fields like "assigned", "milestone", or "project" to track progress.
comments:
Thank you for reporting this issue! We've added this to our internal tracking system.
ID: PM-19047

Hi @frq-asgard-josi and thank you for your report.

Bitwarden uses [https-proxy-agent](https://www.npmjs.com/package/https-proxy-agent) to handle proxied connections on the CLI. This is either an upstream issue or we might need to switch over to using [proxy-agent](https://www.npmjs.com/package/proxy-agent) from the same maintainer, which proxies 😂 calls based on the set env-variables.

Mid/Long-term, Bitwarden CLI will likely benefit moving over to using native NodeJS fetch support and proxy via [undici](https://github.com/nodejs/undici). I looked into this a while ago, but it hasn't been a priority to migrate.

Marking this as good first issue, in case anyone would like to start investigating.

Kind regards,
Daniel

repository.description: Bitwarden client apps (web, browser extension, desktop, and cli).
repository.name: clients

summary.main: The 'no_proxy' env var is not being evaluated for the Bitwarden CLI, causing the CLI to use the proxy instead of respecting the 'no_proxy' env var. This affects the expected behavior and can be observed on Linux.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the Bitwarden CLI to respect the 'no_proxy' env var and not use the proxy.
summary.attemptedFixes: The fix can be implemented by investigating and resolving the issue in https-proxy-agent or proxy-agent. This can be achieved by looking into proxies, environment variables, and upstream issues.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is currently labeled as 'bug', 'cli', 'help wanted', and 'good first issue', indicating it's a significant issue suitable for a contributor to tackle. According to the comments, the issue might be caused by a bug in https-proxy-agent or proxy-agent, and upstream Fix PRs/Issues need to be checked. A pull request should be submitted targeting the main branch with explanations of the fix if possible.

issueDTO.title: Make it so that the display configuration auto reloads
issueDTO.description:
## Requirements
- When a user modifies the display configuration, we should automatically reload it. See the regular miracle config for inspiration!
- If the configuration has any issues, we should abandon the reload and make sure that we haven't applied any changes yet

## Future Requirement
- Publish any errors to the client (somehow!) so that they can view them on the screen (in a similar way to how i3 tells you when your config is incorrect). This same mechanism should be used for the regular miracle config too. This should be a separate task!

repository.description: Miracle is a Wayland tiling window manager built on Mir
repository.name: miracle-wm

summary.main: The display configuration should auto-reload when a user makes modifications, and if issues arise, it should abandon the reload and prevent changes from being applied. Future requirements include publishing any errors to the client for viewing and implementing this for the regular miracle config.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is that when a user modifies the display configuration, it auto-reloads without applying any changes. If the configuration has any issues, the process should abandon the reload and prevent any changes from being applied.
summary.attemptedFixes: To address this issue, the implementer can refer to the regular miracle config for inspiration on how to implement the automatic reload feature. Additionally, error publishing is mentioned as a future requirement, which should be implemented separately.
summary.otherNotes: This issue has been labeled as 'good first issue', indicating it's suitable for a contributor to tackle. The issue description provides context on the required functionality for the display configuration auto-reload system.

issueDTO.title: feat(tests): port ethereum/tests test cases (tracking issue)
issueDTO.description:
This is a top-level issue for tracking the manual porting of ethereum/tests test cases to execution-spec-tests:

> **Contributions to manually port individual test cases are very welcome!**

**If you're already familiar with ethereum/tests and execution-spec-tests, jump to the issue tracker below!**

#### Background
[ethereum/tests](https://github.com/ethereum/tests) was the repository used to define EVM test cases from [Frontier](https://ethereum.org/en/history/#frontier) up to and including [The Merge](https://ethereum.org/en/history/#paris). The test cases are defined as YAML (and sometimes JSON) files in the [./src/ sub-directory](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src) and the JSON "test fixtures" (fully-populated tests that can be executed against clients) are generated using [ethereum/retesteth](https://github.com/ethereum/retesteth). These JSON artifacts are regenerated when required and added to the repository, for example, in the [./GeneralStateTests/ sub-directory](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/GeneralStateTests).

From [Shanghai](https://ethereum.org/en/history/#shapella) on, new test cases (in particular for new features included in hard-forks) have been defined in Python in this repository (execution-spec-tests). The existing test cases are still important to execute against clients, however, and porting ethereum/tests to execution-spec-tests ensures that the test cases can be continually maintained and filled (generated) for newer forks. It also has the advantage that client teams will only need to obtain test fixture releases from one source.

#### Automated Port to Python
Although there will be an effort to automate ("transpile") the remaining test cases from YAML (respectively JSON) to Python; contributions to manually port individual test cases can be very beneficial and are welcome! 

The benefits of manual porting are:
1. Reduce the number of test cases by combing multiple YAML (resp. JSON) test cases in one Python test function (via parametrization).
2. Potentially improve coverage by parametrizing the Python version.
3. Code/docstrings are likely higher quality than an automated conversion.
4. The test can be better [organized within the `./tests` folder](https://ethereum.github.io/execution-spec-tests/main/writing_tests/adding_a_new_test/) in execution-spec-tests by the fork and the EIP in which the functionality was introduced.

#### Process
1. Pick a single or a set of YAML test cases in ethereum/tests to port and create an issue in this repository - optional, but definitely recommended if porting tests from the tracker below to avoid duplicate work.
2. Create a PR with the ported tests:
    a. Add the list of ported YAML files to [converted-ethereum-tests.txt](https://github.com/ethereum/execution-spec-tests/blob/1b30c336eae6b0746ea4db441ac74406f2fb2322/converted-ethereum-tests.txt).
    b. If the tests can't currently be filled, please explain the issue (feel free to also [open a Discussion](https://github.com/ethereum/execution-spec-tests/discussions/new?category=general)).

#### Help with ethereum/tests

The test formats are described in the [ethereum/tests online docs](https://ethereum-tests.readthedocs.io/en/latest/blockchain-ref.html). Note that state filler test cases in YAML can be parametrized, see the [docs here](https://ethereum-tests.readthedocs.io/en/latest/test_filler/state_filler.html#the-indexes).

#### Hints to Get Started with ethereum/execution-spec-tests

0. Start here: [Getting Started â†’ Installation](https://ethereum.github.io/execution-spec-tests/main/getting_started/installation/).
1. Use `uv run et make test` to create a template test module (currently a WIP in #950).
2. Where to put the test? See how tests are organized in [Writing Tests â†’ Adding a New Test](https://ethereum.github.io/execution-spec-tests/main/writing_tests/adding_a_new_test/).
3. State vs Blockchain test? If in doubt try to write a state test, see [Writing Tests â†’ Types of Tests â†’ Deciding on a Test Type](https://ethereum.github.io/execution-spec-tests/main/writing_tests/types_of_tests/#deciding-on-a-test-type).
4. Tests are filled via EELS by default (no further installation necessary; it's a Python dependency and got installed in Step 0), see [Filling  â†’ Getting Started](https://ethereum.github.io/execution-spec-tests/main/filling_tests/getting_started/).
5. Parametrizing test functions is encouraged, see [Writing Tests â†’ Writing a New Test â†’ Parametrizing Tests](https://ethereum.github.io/execution-spec-tests/main/writing_tests/writing_a_new_test/#parametrizing-tests).
6. The Opcode mini-lang defined in this repository is the preferred way to define bytecode in tests (if feasible). For a very simple example, see [`test_chainid()`](https://github.com/ethereum/execution-spec-tests/blob/85393456e75f5f3b476cb5e61c35d48172f9d543/tests/istanbul/eip1344_chainid/test_chainid.py#L28) - there are other examples in the tests.

Feel free to reach out for help or guidance in the Ethereum R&D discord or via DM; see [Getting Help](https://ethereum.github.io/execution-spec-tests/main/getting_started/getting_help/) in the docs.

```[tasklist]
### Test Cases
- [ ] Add test cases for any single opcode (porting an entire test case from ethereum/tests can be overwhelming; instead add your own test cases for a single opcode from https://www.evm.codes/).
- [x] [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/VMTests/vmTests](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/VMTests/vmTests) - swapFiller.yml - WIP: ethereum/execution-spec-tests#1012
- [x] [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/VMTests/vmTests](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/VMTests/vmTests) - dupFiller.yml.
- [x] [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/VMTests/vmTests](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/VMTests/vmTests) - pushFiller.yml - WIP: ethereum/execution-spec-tests#974
- [ ] [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/VMTests/vmTests](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/VMTests/vmTests) (Note: DUP already ported).
- [ ] [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stLogTests/](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/4f65a0a7cbecf4442415c226c65e089acaaf6a8b/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stLogTests).
- [ ] [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stRandom](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stRandom) and [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stRandom2](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stRandom2) (see #1016 for details)
- [ ] [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stZeroKnowledge](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stZeroKnowledge) and [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stZeroKnowledge2](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stZeroKnowledge2) (see #1016 for details)
- [ ] [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stPreCompiledContracts1](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stPreCompiledContracts1) and [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stPreCompiledContracts2](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stPreCompiledContracts2) (see #1016 for details)
- [ ] [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stQuadraticComplexityTest](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stQuadraticComplexityTest) (see #1016 for details)
- [ ] [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stSStoreTest](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stSStoreTest) (see #1016 for details)
- [ ] [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stTimeConsuming](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stTimeConsuming) (see #1016 for details)
- [ ] [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stWalletTest](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stWalletTest) (see #1016 for details)
- [ ] [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stCallCodes](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stCallCodes), [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stCallDelegateCodesCallCodeHomestead](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stCallDelegateCodesCallCodeHomestead) and [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stCallDelegateCodesHomestead](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stCallDelegateCodesHomestead) (see #1016 for details)
- [ ] [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stEIP150singleCodeGasPrices](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stEIP150singleCodeGasPrices) (see #1016 for details)
```

#### Some Examples of Ported Tests

| ethereum/tests | ethereum/execution-spec-tests|
|---------------------|------------------------------------------|
| [src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/VMTests/vmTests/dupFiller.yml](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/blob/4f65a0a7cbecf4442415c226c65e089acaaf6a8b/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/VMTests/vmTests/dupFiller.yml) | [tests/frontier/opcodes/test_dup.py](https://github.com/ethereum/execution-spec-tests/blob/1b30c336eae6b0746ea4db441ac74406f2fb2322/tests/frontier/opcodes/test_dup.py) |
| [GeneralStateTests/stCreate2/call_outsize_then_create2_successful_then_returndatasize.json](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/blob/4f65a0a7cbecf4442415c226c65e089acaaf6a8b/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stCreate2/call_outsize_then_create2_successful_then_returndatasizeFiller.json), [GeneralStateTests/stCreate2/call_then_create2_successful_then_returndatasize.json](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/blob/4f65a0a7cbecf4442415c226c65e089acaaf6a8b/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/stCreate2/call_then_create2_successful_then_returndatasizeFiller.json)| [tests/constantinople/eip1014_create2/test_create_returndata.py](https://github.com/ethereum/execution-spec-tests/blob/1b30c336eae6b0746ea4db441ac74406f2fb2322/tests/constantinople/eip1014_create2/test_create_returndata.py) |

summary.main: The main issue is to manually port Ethereum test cases from the ethereum/tests repository to the execution-spec-tests repository. This involves porting individual test cases, creating pull requests, and adding links to converted YAML files to the repository.
summary.validationOrRequirement: According to the issue, the expected behavior is for test cases to be manually ported to ensure high-quality code and docstrings. The manual porting process allows contributors to focus on individual test cases and improve coverage and quality.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue notes that manual porting is preferred over automated porting, and suggests that contributors start by porting a single opcode test case. It also recommends creating a pull request with the ported tests and adding a link to the converted YAML files to the repository.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is a tracking issue for manually porting Ethereum test cases to the execution-spec-tests repository. The issue notes that manual porting is recommended due to the complexity of some test cases and the potential for higher quality code/docstrings. Contributors are encouraged to pick a single or set of YAML test cases and create an issue for each one. The issue also provides links to resources and guidance on how to get started with porting tests.

issueDTO.title: MSBuildLogger Does Not Handle When the File is Null
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**
In the MSBuild Logger of NuGetDefense.Core, the Log Methods always expect the file paramter to be non-null and do not handle nulls well. 

**Expected behavior**
When File is null, instead log "NuGetDefense" as the origin.


**Additional context**
Tests for MSBuildLogger's methods need to be added with this  fix.
This is from the NuGetDefense.Core Project: https://github.com/digitalcoyote/NuGetDefense.Core

repository.description: An MSBuildTask that checks for known vulnerabilities. Inspired by OWASP SafeNuGet.
repository.name: NuGetDefense

summary.main: The MSBuildLogger in NuGetDefense.Core does not handle cases where the file parameter is null, expecting it to always be non-null, and this issue needs to be addressed to improve the logger's functionality.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the MSBuild Logger to log 'NuGetDefense' as the origin when the file parameter is null.
summary.attemptedFixes: A fix can be implemented by modifying the MSBuild Logger's Log Methods to handle null values for the file parameter.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is labeled as 'bug' and 'good first issue', indicating it's a significant issue suitable for a contributor to tackle.

issueDTO.title: Volcano job natively support Ray framework
issueDTO.description:
### What is the problem you're trying to solve

Ray is a popular AI framework that has been widely used, and ray operator has already supported Volcano as a batch scheduler, seeï¼šhttps://github.com/ray-project/kuberay
On the other hand, many users still use volcano job to run their job instead of new ray APIï¼Œso it's reasonable to support ray natively on volcano job.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Currently volcano supports distributed AI and HPC framework like pytorch, tensorflow,  mpi.
Just like what vcjobs currently do, and a new plugin named `ray` in pkg/controllers/job/plugins/distributed-framework, so users can submit a vcjob and actually run a ray job.

### Additional context

issueDTO.title: Is it worth lowering the cost of `equalsData` in the `False` case?
issueDTO.description:
#7138 lowers down the cost of `equalsData` when the two `Data` objects aren't equal. It would be great to have lower cost for `equalsData`, but implementing it properly is quite challenging, so we should first check if the impact is worth the trouble.

This issue is for replaying all the on-chain evaluation events using the #7138 branch recording the budget and success results. We're interested in:

- what percentage (+ an absolute number) of total script executions gets 0-1% cheaper
- 2-5%
- 5-10%
- 10-15%
- ...
- 95-100%
- whether any of the script executions gets more expensive (that would be a bug)
comments:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6b78ed2a-83f4-4234-9cf8-867d065d8f4b)

[Meeting notes](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1eeR1sy2FrwOnUhW6yMCLzYQ3ttK5PiAQi-r9mrBl5jo/edit?usp=sharing)

repository.description: The Plutus language implementation and tools
repository.name: plutus

summary.main: The issue describes a potential optimization of the equalsData function in the Plutus language implementation and tools, aiming to lower the cost of the function when the two Data objects are not equal.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The requirement is to evaluate the impact of lowering the cost of equalsData in the False case, specifically focusing on the percentage and absolute numbers of script executions that get cheaper, and ensuring no scripts get more expensive.
summary.attemptedFixes: The expected behavior is for the equalsData function to have a lower cost in the False case. However, implementing the fix might be challenging as mentioned in the issue description.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is labeled as 'Low priority' and 'Good first issue', indicating it's a minor concern suitable for a contributor to tackle. A pull request should be submitted targeting the main branch with relevant metrics (percentage and absolute numbers) on script execution cost changes.

issueDTO.title: Display language information to pois
issueDTO.description:
### Motivation
In our target group interviews, we (= target group team) got the input, that end users are insecure about going to pois, because they do not know if the language they know are spoken there. As which language is spoken is very different for every location, we want a text field, and hope the cms users will fill it with, e.g. "on thursday afternoon russian, on other days only german an englisch", or similar.


### Proposed Solution
<!-- A clear and concise description of the feature you would like to add, and how it solves the motivating problem. -->
Show the text that can be entered in the cms for every poi containing information about languages in web and native.

### Alternatives
<!-- A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or features you've considered, and why you're proposed solution is better. -->
We discussed if we just tell the cms users to add this information to the description field, but having this field is a constant reminder and as it is a important feature for the target group, we decided adding this field is the best way to go.

### User Story
<!-- A clear description of the User Stories that should be achieved by the new feature. The User Stories should follow this pattern:-->
As a app user I want know if at a poi my language is spoken so that I know if it is worth for me to go there.

### Additional Context
<!-- Add any other information or screenshots about the feature request here. -->
See: https://openproject.tuerantuer.org/projects/community-feedback/work_packages/3231/activity

### Design Requirements
<!-- If the customization includes input from our design team, the detailed requirements will be collected here. Note: These will exist mainly in German to simplify internal communication. -->
None.

blocked by https://github.com/digitalfabrik/integreat-cms/issues/2799
comments: Duplicated in https://github.com/digitalfabrik/integreat-app/issues/2822 (might have additional information).

As discussed with @osmers in https://github.com/digitalfabrik/integreat-cms/issues/2799, the CMS team doesn't have this on their roadmap for the next three months but might implement the API endpoint returning an undefined soon-ish so that we can already work with that. The CMS can then implement the actual adding of languages later on; this would have the advantage of the municipalities being able to see their changes immediately in the app.

Design is ready and can be found [📌 here](https://www.figma.com/design/cA4F2MwHs2LNGviOWUjfE9/Integreat-Tickets-Frontend?node-id=4935-882&t=kGFrHSyaGLrKSPlZ-1). Let me know your thoughts @steffenkleinle @LeandraH

issueDTO.title: Camunda/Zeebe SDK Client silently accepts configuration issue
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug** **To Reproduce** 1. Checkout and build [Camunda Example Twitter](https://github.com/camunda-community-hub/camunda-8-examples/tree/main/twitter-review-java-springboot) 2. Set appropriate configuration properties to connect to your cluster/instance ``` zeebe.client.cloud.clusterId=... zeebe.client.cloud.clientId=SJqG7ve.... zeebe.client.cloud.clientSecret=... zeebe.client.cloud.region=... zeebe.client.cloud.auth-url=... zeebe.client.cloud.base-url=... ``` 3. Set environment variable ``` ZEEBE_CLIENT_CONFIG_PATH=/tmp ``` 4. Run the application and see some errors on the console regarding authentication issues. ``` at io.camunda.zeebe.client.impl.ZeebeClientFutureImpl.join(ZeebeClientFutureImpl.java:52) ~[zeebe-client-java-8.6.7.jar:8.6.7] ... 32 common frames omitted Caused by: io.grpc.StatusRuntimeException: UNAUTHENTICATED: HTTP status code 401 invalid content-type: text/html headers: Metadata(:status=401,date=Fri, 24 Jan 2025 14:49:06 GMT,content-type=text/html,www-authenticate=Bearer token_type="JWT",strict-transport-security=max-age=63072000; includeSubDomains,content-length=172) DATA----------------------------- 401 Authorization Required

401 Authorization Required

nginx
``` **Expected behavior** For a better developer experience, the client should at least log an error to the console. But ideally should abort the bootstrapping with a useful error message mentioning which property is wrongly configured. **Log/Stacktrace** 👀 **We do indeed raise an exception, when a directory is configured instead of a file (see [here](https://github.com/camunda/camunda/blob/ed8a807969f040fdb55b575a9e31fef957fd8d5e/clients/java/src/main/java/io/camunda/zeebe/client/impl/oauth/OAuthCredentialsProviderBuilder.java#L251)) and the exception bubbles up to `PropertyUtil.java` (see [here](https://github.com/camunda/camunda/blob/cbef3b18134bbd4198456c293206bef2eab726f9/clients/spring-boot-starter-camunda-sdk/src/main/java/io/camunda/zeebe/spring/client/configuration/PropertyUtil.java#L98)) where the error is logged with `DEBUG` level!** 👀 Thus in order to see the message on the console the log level of the spring application needs to be changed (You will still see a lot of noise on the log, because the client still continues to bootstrap) ``` logging.level.root=DEBUG ``` See stack trace and error message below.
Full Stacktrace

repository.description: Process Orchestration Framework
repository.name: camunda

summary.main: The Camunda/Zeebe SDK Client silently accepts a configuration property that is not a file, but instead a directory. This causes authentication issues and errors in the client.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the client to raise an exception when a directory is specified as a credentials cache, and not silently accept it. This would provide a better developer experience and help prevent errors caused by misconfigured credentials.
summary.attemptedFixes: To fix this issue, the client should log an error or abort the bootstrapping process if the specified credentials cache is a directory instead of a file. The legacy property method can also be modified to handle this issue.
summary.otherNotes: The GitHub issue is about the Camunda/Zeebe SDK Client silently accepting a configuration issue. It describes a bug where the client silently accepts a configuration property that is not a file, but instead a directory. This might lead to authentication issues and errors in the client. The issue is labeled as 'bug', 'good first issue', and 'support'.

issueDTO.title: [BUG] Unable to load XML files
issueDTO.description:
<!-- âš ï¸âš ï¸ Do not delete this template âš ï¸âš ï¸ -->

<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Playwright release to see if your issue has already been fixed -->
<!-- 💡 Provide enough information for us to be able to reproduce your issue locally -->

### System info
- Playwright Version: v1.52.3
- Operating System: Debian 12
- Browser: Chromium
- Other info:

### Source code
N/A

**Steps**
- Make a request for a valid XML file (e.g. https://www.aldi.nl/sitemaps/.aldi-nord-sitemap-products.xml)

**Expected**
- Playwright successfully requests the file and the contents is correctly loaded

**Actual**
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fb4f7437-894a-49c2-b79d-e706b4f1a5de)
(we get an `xmlParseEntityRef: no name` error)

**Extra Notes**
- The bug only manifests when using chrome (either the google-stable binary or the playwright bundled chrome); firefox is unaffected and successfully loads the XML file.
- If we run without patchright and just use vanilla playwright (with exactly the same chrome browser binary, args etc.) the XML file is requested and loaded without issue
- Issue is also not present with Rebrowser+Puppeteer+Chrome. The only combo that triggers this bug is patchright+chrome)

repository.description: Undetected version of the Playwright testing and automation library.

summary.main: The issue description states that users are unable to load XML files using Playwright, specifically reporting a 'xmlParseEntityRef: no name' error when requesting https://www.aldi.nl/sitemaps/.aldi-nord-sitemap-products.xml, with the error only occurring when using Chrome in combination with patchright.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for Playwright to successfully request and load XML files without errors, whether running with patchright or vanilla playwright settings, and without any browser-specific issues.
summary.attemptedFixes: Further investigation is required to diagnose and resolve the issue as observed. Relevant information includes the Linux-based Debian 12's Chromium browser numbers v1.52.3, XML file request steps, error logs, testing under alternative browsers and frameworks.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is currently labeled as 'bug' and 'good first issue', indicating it's a significant issue suitable for a contributor to tackle. A pull request should be submitted targeting the main branch with before/after screenshots or video if possible.

issueDTO.title: feat: support inserting documents as a trait
issueDTO.description:
- [x] I have looked for existing issues (including closed) about this

## Feature Request
<!--
High level description of the requested feature or improvement.
-->
Currently, every vector store provider integration that we have has an `insert_documents` method. It would be a great idea to formalise this as a trait. By doing so:
- We can reference this method without the compiler needing to know what type it is
- We can ensure that this behaviour is guaranteed across vector stores.

This would also be a good chance to implement a new, different type of `insert_docs` method that also takes a user-defined ID generation strategy (although perhaps out of initial scope for the first PR).

### Motivation
<!--
Please describe the use case(s) or other motivation for the new feature.
-->
Better UX, better type reusability.

### Proposal
<!--
How should the new feature be implemented, and why? Add any considered
drawbacks.
-->
Move all `insert_document` methods under a new `InsertDocuments` trait.

### Alternatives
<!--
Are there other ways to solve this problem that you've considered? What are
their potential drawbacks? Why was the proposed solution chosen over these
alternatives?
-->
comments: RIG-790 feat: support inserting documents as a trait

summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is to formalize the `insert_documents` method as a trait, ensuring consistency and guaranty across vector store integrations. This would also enable the introduction of a new, user-defined ID generation strategy in the future.
summary.attemptedFixes: Implementing the feature involves moving all `insert_document` methods under a new `InsertDocuments` trait, as described in the proposal. This aligns with the motivation for better UX and reusability of types. Potential drawbacks include discussion and consideration of alternative solutions.

issueDTO.description:
### Self Checks
